briefing.opening: Good morning, everyone. We will now commence the climate briefing for January 4, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Climate Crisis: Direct Threats to Human Life, Economy, and Ecosystems Domestically and Internationally
sections.content: Human casualties and property damage due to extreme weather are snowballing domestically, with heatwave-related deaths accounting for the majority [1, 3]. Internationally, climate change is estimated to cause a 12% reduction in U.S. income [17], and in already vulnerable regions like Madagascar, it is exacerbating poverty and accelerating the crisis [24]. Ecosystems also face severe threats, with U.S. surfing hotspots endangered by coastal erosion [21], and concerns raised that Scottish pine trees could face extinction [26]. Furthermore, climate change is impacting the health sector, increasing the global threat of brain-eating amoebas [23]. While this tangible suffering is easily felt, studying it is becoming increasingly difficult [16].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Policies and Acceleration of Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: Domestically, proactive movements to address climate change are being observed. The Ministry of Climate is operating a climate response fund of 2.9057 trillion Korean Won, the largest ever, to support the transition to a carbon-neutral society [5]. Specifically, South Chungcheong Province is actively launching pilot projects for renewable energy installation, such as generating solar energy in public institution parking lots [11] and pursuing solar projects utilizing idle land with Samsung Display [8, 9, 12]. In 2024, solar power generation accounted for 54.98% of the total new and renewable energy generation, with South Jeolla Province ranking first at 7.86 TWh, indicating an expansion of domestic new and renewable energy supply [13]. Furthermore, the Ministry of Climate, Energy, and Environment plans to encourage the spread of eco-friendly mobility by providing more subsidies for electric motorcycles with excellent charging speed and range [15].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Challenges and Policy Hurdles in Domestic and International Climate Crisis Response
sections.content: Despite efforts to address the climate crisis, a lack of policy consistency remains a significant challenge. A prime example is Jeju Island's disposable cup deposit system, which is at risk of being derailed due to the government's new policy initiatives [14]. The domestic agricultural sector also urgently needs to establish survival strategies for the climate crisis [2], and countermeasures and competitiveness are desperately needed in response to strengthening domestic and international environmental regulations [4]. Internationally, despite the Everglades restoration project being underway for 25 years, climate change is having such a powerful impact that it necessitates a reorientation of the restoration mission [18]. Furthermore, experts' observations that the U.S.'s natural disaster preparedness capabilities were dangerously weakened during the tenure of former U.S. President Donald Trump underscore the importance of political will in responding to the climate crisis [27].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Awareness of Climate Change and Exploration of Response Strategies
sections.content: As reported by the Daily Observer that climate change is affecting weather patterns [25], the international community is confronting the reality of climate change and exploring response measures. The opinion has been put forth that climate change education should be disability-inclusive [19], emphasizing that all members of society must be able to understand and respond to the impacts of climate change. Furthermore, the importance of shifting perceptions on climate change is being highlighted, with arguments being made to reject hindering factors such as fatalism or denial and to actively respond to climate change [20]. Appreciation for the Wisconsin State Journal's editorials and coverage on climate change [22] suggests the crucial role of the media.

briefing.closing: The domestic and international climate threats and response efforts identified in today's briefing once again highlight the complexity of the challenges we face. Emphasizing that sustained attention and cooperation are the only path to building climate resilience, I conclude today's climate briefing.

articles.title: Jeju's 'Disposable Cup Deposit System' Faces Crisis Amid Inconsistent Eco-Friendly Policies
articles.original_title: ì¼ê´€ì„± ì—†ëŠ” ì¹œí™˜ê²½ ì •ì±…ì—â€¦ì œì£¼ â€˜ì¼íšŒìš©ì»µ ë³´ì¦ê¸ˆì œâ€™ ì¢Œì´ˆ ìœ„ê¸°
articles.description: Despite a rebound to a '60% return rate' last year, the provincial government's administrative support for the disposable cup deposit system is inevitably being re-evaluated due to the government's push for a 'separate cup payment system.' Jeju Island, which has actively implemented the disposable cup deposit system since December 2, 2022, along with Sejong, faces uncertainty.

summary.phenomenon: The disposable cup deposit system, implemented in Jeju Province and Sejong City since December 2, 2022, is facing a crisis due to the government's push to introduce a 'separate cup payment system.' Last year, Jeju Province's disposable cup return rate had rebounded to the 60% range.
summary.cause: The government is promoting the introduction of a 'separate cup payment system' to reduce disposable cup use, which has led to a lack of policy consistency with the existing disposable cup deposit system.
summary.outlook: Jeju Province is compelled to comprehensively re-evaluate administrative support for the disposable cup deposit system due to changes in government policy, making the sustainability of the system uncertain.

articles.title: More Subsidies for Electric Motorcycles with Faster Charging Speeds
articles.original_title: ì¶©ì „ ì†ë„ ë¹ ë¥¸ ì „ê¸° ì˜¤í† ë°”ì´ ë³´ì¡°ê¸ˆ ë” ì¤€ë‹¤
articles.description: The government will provide more subsidies for electric motorcycles with faster charging speeds (3 kW per hour or more) and longer single-charge ranges (90 km or more). This year, 7,820 hydrogen passenger cars are also planned for supply. This is part of a broader plan to ensure low-emission vehicles, including electric and hydrogen cars, constitute half of new car sales in Korea starting in 2030.

summary.phenomenon: According to the revised guidelines for the 2026 electric motorcycle supply project subsidy, released by the Ministry of Climate, Energy and Environment on the 4th, more subsidies will be provided for electric motorcycles with a single-charge range of 90 km or more and those with a charging speed of 3 kW per hour or more. This year, 7,820 hydrogen passenger cars are also slated for supply.
summary.cause: The government is pursuing these policies to respond to climate change and protect the environment by expanding the supply of low-emission vehicles.
summary.outlook: With the goal of having low-emission vehicles, including electric and hydrogen cars, account for half of new car sales in Korea starting in 2030, the supply of electric motorcycles and hydrogen cars is expected to further expand.

summary.phenomenon: Concerns have been raised that Scots pine could face extinction.
summary.cause: Climate change has been identified as a cause for the potential extinction of Scots pine.
summary.outlook: There is a possibility that Scots pine could become extinct due to climate change.

articles.title: â€˜The perfect stormâ€™: Trump has left the US less prepared for natural disasters, experts say
articles.description: Emergency managers say the US president has presided over a dangerous erosion in US capacity to prepare for and respond to natural disastersDonald Trump has presided over a dangerous erosion in US capacity to prepare for and respond to natural disasters, according to emergency management experts.The first year of his second term was marked by crackdowns on climate science that produced world-class weather forecasts and the gutting of frontline federal agencies - policies that have left the count

summary.phenomenon: Emergency management experts have indicated that during the presidency of former U.S. President Donald Trump, the U.S. capacity to prepare for and respond to natural disasters dangerously eroded.
summary.cause: The Trump administration's suppression of climate science and policies weakening frontline federal agencies were cited as causes for this diminished capacity.
summary.outlook: These policies have left the U.S. inadequately prepared for natural disasters.
